description.text:
Thunderbirds are go! All 5 of the main Thunderbirds vehicles are here in cookie/biscuit cutter form.
Printed using PLA in their respective colours.

I've printed these to make sure they come out OK and my Nephew helped try them in the kitchen.

Have fun with these.

Printer:

Malyan M180

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20% but doesn't really matter

Notes:

The thinnest walls should be 1.2mm, If the parts print with gaps then either reprint with additional perimeter shells or soften the part with a brief lighter flame etc and pinch the shells together.
I created these by tracing around 2D drawings. Adding the numbers and other details slightly shallower than the outline so they should indent into the dough/mix.

print_settings.Notes:: I've uploaded two versions of coupler, one without support and one with a support that prints pretty well and it's very easy to detach.

description.text:
This is a full printable quadpod/quadruped robot wich uses super cheap sg90 9g servos.
The base already has 4 fixing hole for Arduino mega/due.
There is a plastic coupler for every servo to guarantee a better stability for rotation.

You need to print:
-2 normal leg
-2 mirrored leg
-1 base
-12 coupler (with or without support)

Support are needed only for the legs tips.

In my case I used Arduino due with usbhost shield to use 3D mouse space navigator wireless as a controller (I know Arduino due has an embedded usbhost, but the library I found does not work with usb dongle for space navigator wireless).
The power came from a 1000mAh 2 cell lithium battery, with a 5V 5A regulator for the servos.

EDIT: now with the arduino code! (.rar file with the sources)

Printer:

Santelprint

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

20

Notes:

Support are needed only for the legs tips.

I've uploaded two versions of coupler, one without support and one with a support that prints pretty well and it's very easy to detach.

title: Better Bed Mounting - Folger Tech Kossel revB

description.text:
Edit 2016/08/07 - My new layer cooling has taught me the error of my ways. I've uploaded revised versions of the mount - one is 4.5mm and one is 6.5mm. That is height from below the heated bed, so the 4.5 is just about perfect for the bed and a thin cover (like a PEI sheet) and the 6.5 should be good for glass. I'm not making one for just the bed with no cover because first, you should just get some PEI because it's like printing onto a slurry of unicorn tears and pixie dust - that stuff is magical; and second, that extra 1 or 1.5mm is probably small enough to fit under whatever you have dangling off the side of your hotend.

I had a problem where the heated bed would wiggle because the holes in the acrylic are cut too large for the M3 screws, and I couldn't use larger screws to better fit the mounting plates because the heated bed has only M3 holes.

Additionally I hated trying to hold nuts under the bed, trying to keep them from falling if I needed to make an adjustment.

My first versions had spacing to inset an M3 nylock nut, but then I found M3 brass knurled insert nuts, and I stopped improving the inset version. The ones I've uploaded here work great with nuts I got from Amazon (https://www.amazon.com/M3x5mm-Metric-Threaded-Insert-100pcs/dp/B00Y20YLKY/) and they completely fixed my problem of bed wiggle.

One of the mounts I printed seems to have cracked at the top (2mm tab of plastic that fits over the acrylic), so I've created a new version with an integral spacer, which should help with structural integrity. Even with the crack (on one side of the screw hole) it still holds the bed entirely still, as two points and the upright arm are enough to keep it aligned - the top piece is just there to keep it in place when screwing it on (and extra alignment doesn't hurt).

The part with the integral spacer doesn't need the acrylic disks to act as a standoff. Melt an M3 insert into the bottom (should be flush with the bottom), then the mount slides over the acrylic mounting plates. The notch is a little deeper for the acrylic than the bed because the acrylic sticks out a little farther. There is an upright piece to force alignment with the other points. This part is much taller than necessary in order to facilitate other bed surfaces, such as a glass pane, or un-taped PEI. If you print these solid, you can cut them down or leave them sticking up. Do not try making these from PLA - this part is in contact with the heated bed, and as such may have to deal with 110 degrees or more. ABS or better only - PETG would work. Nylon if you have replaced your hotend.

The acrylic pieces slide between the two printed slats, with the flat side down. The bed (or bed and spacers) sit on top of the upper slat, with the upright section pressing against the edge of the bed. Depending on your printer (mine is printing a little bulky) you may need to do some filing to get the holes to line up. Tighter is better than loose though, as loose is the problem in the first place.

After I'm happy with the melt in version I'll go back and work on the nylock nut version. Or sooner if there is interest. Leave me a comment if you really want the nylock version.

Printer:

Folger Tech Kossel revB

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Doesn't necessarily need 100 percent, but it's such a small part, and you will be so sad if it breaks and you can't use your printer. You will need at least 3 of these (one for each mount point), and you should probably print a few extra just in case to keep in your emergency bits bin.

It prints fine with no supports (the screw holes might get a little sloppy, but no so much that it's a problem), and the back piece is thick enough that even moderate warping won't keep these from working properly - so long as it curls from the bed in the first 10-15 layers, there is enough time for it to start printing flat again before it gets to the parts that need to be flat.

I've been printing them on their back, but printing them on their side would probably improve the strength of the part at the expense of needing to be flat and warp free. Or do both. It's a nickel's worth of filament if you're using something like Hatchbox. Half that if you are using the surprisingly good Folger Tech ABS filament.

Fine Tuning

These are a tight fit for me. My printer is also not super dimensionally accurate (50mm comes out as 52ish).

I needed to smooth the top inside of the part (where the mount touches the bottom of the acrylic) after inserting the knurled nut because it melt-squished the plastic up a little.

I also needed to remove a little from the back in the acrylic space to get the holes to line up perfectly. I designed the part to center, and it seems like the bed aligns more toward the inside of the supports rather than the center. Nothing a minute with a file doesn't fix. And better to remove a little plastic than need to add a little, right?

author: jonnyflash

description.text:
This part is a replacement for the height adjustment tabs on the bottom of a keyboard.

It was developed and tested using the dimensions of Microcenter's basic Inland keyboard.

Yes, the angle at the bottom (45) is too steep for the foot to sit flat initially, but I predict it will start to round the sharp over time and eventually rest on the flat. If it doesn't, I'll upload a version with a modified angle.

The pieces print flat without support, and the cut out tabs allow the parts enough flex to snap in during installation. They can also be removed by hand.

Created using Onshape
Part file is public and free to copy/edit if you have an Onshape account:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/f15c0d02f9011bbf59a6068e/w/72dd53f0ccb6ee60a7ed8393/e/153eea7559638bb4758fe723

Changing the length (originally .85) in sketch 1 should change the overall length of your foot without any further adjustments needed.

No

No

title: Better Dial for MP Select Mini V1

description.text:
Find the dial this printer came with a pain in the butt to use? Here's a replacement dial that's much easier to use. The hole at the bottom is made to be snug, don't want that slipping off. To install, remove old dial. It takes a little bit of force, but you can wiggle it on and it'll be nice and tight.

Ok, it seems some people are having difficulty removing the original dial. People have successfully been using dental floss. Work the floss so that it gets behind the dial and pull to remove. No screws need to be removed.

title: Oculus Rift CV1 Desktop Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
After I designed the wall mount for my Oculus some requested a desktop mount and here it is, enjoy!

It is very easy and quick to place and grab the headset and you do not need any extra weight, it is quite stable as is. However if you'd like to make it even more stable the mount pillar is hollow into which you can glue weights. Alse there are four holes for rare earth magnets if you would rather place it on a metal surface. Dimensions of the magnets is D5x2mm.

Dimensions of whole mount is WxLxH=150x198x176mm. For those that can't fit the whole object in their printer I've made a split version. The top part must then be printed with support.

Shapeways: https://www.shapeways.com/product/HA659TLND/oculus-rift-cv1-desktop-mount

Note: Some pictures show the older version that is slightly taller and uses more material.

Added a stand and diffuser lens designed to use this LED module https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00INIIJLI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 that comes with a remote and a bunch of nifty functions. The module will operate off 3 AAA batts but there is a hole in the stand to accept a common USB cable I cut the end off and soldered into the module and ditched the base weight\battery cover then cut a clearance hole for the wire. I used one of these cables https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01222EM7A/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1, cut the micro USB end off, then soldered the power wires directly into the modules pos/neg batt terminals. I printed the lens in clear PLA at 50% infill. Pic shows LED module seperate from the base (with silver weight disk) that gets tossed. Here is the amazing cellular lamp http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19104/#remixes by nervoussystem. Big thanks for posting such a cool project for us!!!

description.text:
Figured it was about time I shared something I've made. This is a simple adapter to be able to use your Milwaukee lithium batteries with your Ryobi tools. There are four total parts to print and then a few pieces necessary to assemble.

Here's a quick youtube video I made of the assembly:
https://youtu.be/78Nx49VKUew

Everything fits a bit tight together (particularly onto the Milwaukee tool), so I might need to increase the tolerances later. I printed all the pieces in ABS, but might try another in Nylon 910 to see if it is a little more "slippery" (for battery insertion) and overall more durable.

Basically this is all you'll need to assemble:
(1) Small copper sheet, 3/32" thick
(4) #8 x 3/4" screws (or just epoxy it together)
(2) 3/8" D x 5/8" L compression springs
(2) 1/8" x 1/4" rivets (or small machine screws of your choice)
(1) wire (I used lamp cord)

Let me know what you think!

If you make this, it's at your own risk! Be very careful with the wiring!
Some of the protections that I believe are monitored by the other pins in the milwaukee battery (overcurrent? under voltage?) of course aren't going to work, so just be careful about how hard you run the tools. Running too low a voltage will damage your cells and I believe the under voltage cutoff is disabled.﻿

author: SgtMunger

description.text:
This block makes it easy to fasten a flashlight to your bike's handlebars by cradling both the bar and the light and properly capturing several zip ties.  It's sized with a 24 mm diameter for the handlebar side (remember to put something grippy around the bar, like a strip of rubber) and a 20 mm diameter on the flashlight side.   
The zip tie holes have chamfers on the upper side to make bridging easier, although the gap is small.  
The original Solidworks file is included, if you want to adjust dimensions.

Print with solid infill.  FIne layers will make it stronger.  ABS and Nylon will be more weather-resistant than PLA, but any material will work.  It took about 40 minutes on my RepRap with 0.2 mm layers.

description.text:
I originally designed this thing as a test for using Proto Pasta's high-temperature carbon fiber filament, but the test print I did in plain old PLA actually works pretty well. PLA is not really food safe because you can't clean it in really hot water, but if you are just pressing garlic with it (and not, say, meat) and the rinse it well afterwords, you probably won't die.

UPDATE: In addition the attractive classic version with the round well, I've added an easy-squeeze, easy-clean version with a square well.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

I used 4 perimeters to make sure it is really sturdy. You should also print it pretty hot and slow to make sure the layers fuse completely.

For the classic round version, use the files body.stl, lever.stl and plunger.stl. For the easy-clean version, use the files body2.stl, lever.stl and plunger2.stl. Note: you will need to use a raft when printing plunger2.stl.
I used 0.25" outer dia x 0.625" long nylon spacers for the pivot pins. You could also use short pieces of 0.25" dia brass, aluminum or steel rod. All should be available at most hardware stores.

comments.author: Tamatoacoco

comments.text: ABS gets used for tons of things that end up in your mouth ( https://www.amazon.com/Yamaha-recorder-soprano-Baroque-YRS-38BIII/dp/B001PPNRWC ). And sure, some lead may leach from brass into PLA, and then into your garlic, but how much? And yes, some garlic borne bacteria may linger in the nooks and crannies of the PLA, but is it harmful? If we are worrying about unknowns, personally, I'm much more worried about what is hiding in almost any packaged food and than I am about the dangers of most 3D printed kitchenware, as long as you use a little common sense (like not storing mayonnaise in 3D printed containers).
comments.author: ArnieX

comments.text: I really only have experience printing this in PLA.  Are your ABS parts breaking along the layer lines?  With ABS it is very difficult to get layer fusing for full-strength parts without an acetone vapor bath.

title: SevenSwitch Mount for Prusa i3 OR generic circuit board to rod connector

description.text:
This is a small mount to put a sevenswitch (http://reprap.org/wiki/SevenSwitch_1.2) on one of the threaded rods which make up the lower frame of the RepRap Prusa i3. By changing the parameters I could attach any rectangular thing with four holes in the corners to any round thing. I made the plate thickness the same as the cylinder wall thickness. I made the plate corner radius the same as the standoff radius.

I haven't found a good way to print it. I did it with the standoffs pointed down and some support, and slic3r still made some crazy bridges, which worked ok but looked ugly. I didn't try again, since the first try worked fine. I thought about using a hull to connect the cylinder to the plate, but then I wouldn't have a good place to secure machine screws underneath.

Updated 18-July-2016 to make the output stl manifold, thanks to Sir_Death for pointing out my error.

Anyway, I hope this helps someone or serves as a starting point for something useful.

Supports:

Yes

comments.text:
the 2nd "union" inside the "difference" is making the "not mainfold" - you have to union all the parts going together, but there is no need to union all the holes.
Difference takes the first line as main object and substracts every following line - no matter how much there are.
comments.author: Sir_Death

comments.text: Aha! Thank you, Sir_Death. I don't exactly understand why that should matter to the manifold-ness of the part, but with that change it is indeed fixed.

title: bubba water bottle handle replacement
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the first file I've designed I thought was decent enough to upload. It still isn't perfect as I rushed to make it, but right off the printer it's pretty much ready to go.

I recently bought a bubba 24 ounce insulated water bottle for work, and within a week a dropped it and broke the handle. Superglue wouldn't hold so I decided to try and make a replacement.

When printing I would use either a brim or a raft to help with the bed adhesion and support material with parts touching the print bed as putting support material everywhere would most likely mess with the holes where it attaches to the water bottle. Once you print it you will have to sand down the rounded parts by the mounting holes so the handle will lay flush against the water bottle.

Again this is not a perfect design but it definitely helps in a pinch. It may possibly work with other water bottles as well.

comments.text: Had this break on mine too.

print_settings.Notes:: http://www.ebay.com/itm/111384500750?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&var=410367780401&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

description.text:
This is a 445nm 2.5W laser diode mount with support for two line lasers for positioning.

There is a battery holder for a C2025 battery and push button switch to power the line lasers. I glued it on the back of the laser mount with super glue after wiring it.

The 2.5W laser is from eBay. http://www.ebay.com/itm/231968432876?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

The line lasers also from ebay. http://www.ebay.com/itm/222120750683

A word of caution if you buy the 2.5W Laser Diode mentioned above. Mine had the TTL input wires reversed. The seller was notified and has since corrected the photo showing the diodes polarity. The white wire is + and the blue wire is - and what they don't tell you is that if the TTL input is left open and not connected to anything, when you plug in the 12 Volt supply, the laser will activate! Be very careful with these lasers as they are dangerous and you should always were protective goggles when around them.

I modified the Marlin software to output the FAN to a 5 volt TTL PWM logic level on the RAMPS 1.4 board since I drive the RAMPS at 12 volts and the D9 output would damage the diode driver. I will provide more information on this later.

EDIT: Added original MPCNC version. Note: I have no way to test this as I only have the updated MPCNC machine, but I took the part that mounts to the CNC machine from another stl file and hacked it to fit my laser mount.

author: tmurabrun

description.text: Boxes based on a stack of 150 small cubes. Some are traditional boxes with lids; others are made of 6 pieces which lock together. The pieces consist of a bottom, 4 identical sides, and a lid. The sides stack vertically, head to foot, to make taller boxes. The pieces can be printed in different colors to show the interesting pattern created by the locking tabs. OpenSCAD code is included.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3 mm

The boxes and pieces come in 3 sizes; 20 mm -tiny-, 40 mm -default- and 80 mm - big-. A parameter in the openSCAD code, "clearance", adjsts the clearances for the tabs and holes to make parts which lock together. The same clearance was used for all the boxes, it makes the holes a bit over 1 mm larger than the tabs. There is more information in the openSCAD code.

This is a replacement for '93 VW Eurovan Weekender sliding curtain hangers. My daughter and son-in-law couldn't find replacements, so I modeled this in blender and printed a copy. I used Taulman 910 nylon and the hangers are very strong and worked out well without post-printing "sculpting." I also printed some in ABS which seemed like they would be fine, but I only sent the nylon version. I printed these in pairs and finally in threes, which seemed to work out a little better than singles.
I'll post photos of the the final print this week. The working version is cruising around California now doing its job.

description.text:
A model of the Millau Viaduct.
The Millau Viaduct is a cable-stayed bridge that spans the valley of the River Tarn near Millau in southern France.

Assembly Guide:

  • Print all of the components.
  • Glue the Bridge Top to the Bridge Deck.
  • Glue the Bridge Bottom to the Bridge Deck
  • Glue the Suspension Cables to the Bridge Deck in the Deck recesses, the loose cable side will rest on the Bridge Top.
  • Optional: Glue each of the loose Suspension Cables to the Bridge Top
rbox - The reading box for preschoolers. Phonics teaching of CVC (consonant-vowel-consonant), CCVC, CVCC, CVVC and CVCe (consonant-vowel-consonant-e).

Printer:

Delta Printer Kit

Resolution:

any (I used 0.3 mm layer height)

Infill:

15% with 2 wall thickness for strength.

Notes:

Printing the letters blocks:
Letter blocks can be printed in multiple color (using pause command to change filament at layers) or print it in one color then paint the letter afterwards. To print in multiple color, the color change should be done at layer height 0.6mm, that is after 2 layers for 0.3mm resolution.
Printing the letters 2 each is a good idea for extras and for words using double letters.

Printing the cover (rbox_02.stl):
The cover can be printed in single color, to add two tone effect on the rbox logo color change should be that at height 0.6mm. The cover will be stiff to slide at first, the tracks will need to wear off to have a smoother slide. It can also be lightly sanded, in my case I put small amount of baby powder for it to slide smoothly, this will also need to be done to the other sliding parts.

Printing the letter slot (rbox_01.stl):
The letter slot can be printed in single color, but one can change color at desired height to add two tone effect.

Printing the storage (rbox_03.stl or rbox_03a.stl):
The same with letter slot this can be in one color or with two tone effect. I have included two files for this, one have cell dividers and the other does not, this is to store the letter blocks neatly.

Printing the lock (rbox_04.stl)
Nothing fancy here.

Project Name:

rbox

Overview & Background:

As a parent to a toddler and a preschooler, we looked for different ways on how to teach our children to read. With the help of internet we learn about CVC (consonant-vowel-consonant, and of its variation CCVC, CVCC, CVVC and CVCe). A friend teacher advice that we could use word card in a sleeve, then we can slide the sleeve to reveal the letters. I said to myself, what if I could make something that can be more durable than paper, and that we can bring anywhere. Then I designed the rbox.

Objective:

rbox - reading box for preschoolers. With the phonics teaching of CVC, CCVC, CVCC, CVVC and CVCe and rbox, educator/parents/teachers can make learning to read more fun for preschoolers. With the size almost the same as smart phones, learning to read can be anywhere.

Audience:

Preschoolers

Subjects:

reading, phonics, CVC, CVVC, CCVC, CVCC, CVCe

Lesson/Activity:

Internet can provide teachers/parents with the CVC, CCVC, CVVC, CVCC and CVCe words, that they can use to spell it out with the rbox. Using the cover, teacher / parent can slide it to reveal the letters as the child reads them.

rbox can also be used to teach preschoolers to spell 4-letter words.

Since rbox has its own lock and letter storage, reading can be anywhere, even during long drives in the car.

References:

Internet can provide a lot of references for CVC, CCVC, CVVC,CVCC, CVCe words that teachers and parents can use with rbox. This words need to be actual English words not just group of letters.

title: Y-Carriage supported Linear rail upgrade for Geeetech printers

description.text:
If you're reading this, it's probably because (like me) you're sick of constantly re-adjusting the bed height because the 8mm smooth rods flex easily. To make matters worse, the rods on my printer had a slight bend. Soooo, this upgrade replaces the Y-Carriage 8mm smooth rods on GeeeTech printers (and possibly others) with 12mm supported linear rails.

The re-designed y-carriage end supports are a direct replacement for the existing aluminium supports. The rear support also incorporates a built-in mount for an optical endstop sensor.
 
 

You will need:

  • 2 x SBR12-420mm Supported linear rails
  • 4 x SBR12UU Bearing blocks
  • 1 x Optical endstop sensor
  • 2 x M3 nuts and M3 x 10mm bolts. (To mount optical sensor)
  • 16 x M5 washers M5 x 10mm bolts. (To mount Aluminium bed)

All parts are available on eBay.
 
 

Instructions:

  • Unless you have access to another printer, I suggest you print the front & rear end carriage supports, drilling template and endstop blade before dismantling your printer.
  • Remove the existing front & rear Y-Carriage end supports and y_axis smooth rods.
  • Cut 2 slots into the X-Z aluminium frame for the linear rails to sit in. (See photos and drawings for details).
  • Re-assemble your printer using the new Y-carriage end supports and linear rails. (Don't forget to slide on the bearing blocks first).
  • The mounting holes for the new bearings are spaced further apart. So you'll need to drill new mounting holes. Attach the drilling template to the aluminium bed using one of the old bearings. Mark and drill the location of the new holes. - Note...Due to their size and position, the new holes will overlap by a few mm.
  • Install and connect the optical endstop. Unlike micro-switches, optical sensors require a 3rd wire to supply 5volts. If your printer uses the Sanguinololu board, you'll need to bridge out a link on the underside of the board. This connects the middle pin of the endstop connectors to the Sanguinololu 5v supply.
  • Attach the endstop blade to the underside of the aluminium bed. Note...The blade position shown in the drawings are indicative only. I recommend that you accurately position and mark your bed before drilling. Ensure you allow enough room for the bed to stop before the linear bearing hits the rear carriage support.
  • Re-attached y-axis stepper motor, tension pulley and drive belt
     
     

Repositioning the Orign

The longer Y-Axis travel means the bed position relative to the extruder will shift when the bed is homed to the limit switches. This mean when the extruder moves to the orign (ie G1 X0 Y0), the nozzle won't position over the front/left corner of the bed. To compensate for this, set the travel limits in configuration.h as follows:

// Travel limits after homing
#define X_MAX_POS 210
#define X_MIN_POS -10
#define Y_MAX_POS 210
#define Y_MIN_POS -35

title: BotBQ | Open Source 3D Printing BBQ - Extruder v. 0.9.1

description.text:
UPDATE -
12DEC2013 - LATEST TESTS: http://youtu.be/z5DaQHBkGtY After many long hours the BotBQ - The Open Source 3D Printing BBQ is available for you to use yourself! I have detailed pretty much everything you need to get you to your first 3D Printed Burger over at http://BotBQ.org and also in some videos that are listed below. The design may need some adjustments for your particular Hamburger housing, but I am currently working on a parametric version so you can customize it to fit your own syringe/baking tool/whatever you want to have hold your meat. The 3D Printed Food extruders I've seen so far are all amazing and I admire all who has delved into this amazing new world of 3D printing food. While working on the BotBQ extruder design I wanted to break it down into something simple without over-engineering it, which is what I did the first few drafts I made. I designed it to be adaptable to the modified wades block on a Mendel90 but I can see that it could be adapted to fit many extruders easily and you shouldn't need to disassemble too much to get'er up and running. I can see some issues using this on some machines, so I apologize in advance for not testing on other machines. I can see some machines without enough space in the front not being to adaptable right now, but this design will improve over time so please bear with me. Only the extruder is being released right now because I am still designing the complete BotBQ. I am currently working on a couple designs:
  • Mobile BotBQ for outdoor grills
  • Indoor BotBQ that will cook your burgers right after they are printed.
    • I had thought about this concept for a while, but until a discussion on a photo album post from Mark Mosiette between myself, Marcus Link, Nils Hitze, Gina HÃÂÃÂ¤uÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂge , and Florian Horsch it never got off the ground. BUT in that thread is where I got the confidence to make it happen. Thank you to all who have been an inspiration and support to me while I worked on this. Please check out http://BotBQ.org to follow along while I attempt to make a whole 3D printing BBQ up and going. First test of 3D Printed Hamburger: http://youtu.be/Cb8eW15ALv8 Initial nozzle testing for the BotBQ: http://youtu.be/N2yu_I_4fGo BotBQ Extruder Assembly: http://youtu.be/y7bkBnQZIvo Attaching the BotBQ Extruder: http://youtu.be/bljerY1GUKw 3D Printed Food Resources: http://BotBQ.org/services/3d-printed-food/

Goto http://BotBQ.org for all details, but here are a couple links to get you started:
  • BotBQ Extruder BOM: http://botbq.org/bill-of-materials/
  • BotBQ Extruder Assembly: http://botbq.org/botbq-extruder-assembly/
  • Firmware and Software tweaks: http://botbq.org/3d-printer-firmware/
  • 3D Printed Food Resources: http://BotBQ.org/services/3d-printed-food/

Ok, so this is a 2d object for a postscript printer, instead of a 3d printer.
But we have rulers and protractors in the tool list, and there are those out there who may not be so endowed.  So if you've got a printer, and no protractor, you now have no excuse.
I wrote this years ago when I was learning postscript, thought it would be useful here.

The protractor is mildly parametric.  If you don't like the divisions I set up or the size, the file can be edited with a text editor.
Print on a transparency if you want to use this over the object you are measuring, or on paper if you want to put it under the object.   Cut to fit if necessary.
The ruler is not as parametric, you might actually figure out how the code works to adjust it, and units are in inches.  The outside border is the bounding box of the printable area of your device.  (If anyone wants this done differently, let me know.)

I'm working on a polar-polar 3d printer concept. I thought that a tapered roller bearing turntable could be fully printed yet still be pretty precise, where linear printed axes are hard to get running smoothly. Also, the printer would be able to print the entire bearing/table, rather than having to section it. The file is sized for a 140x140mm table.
Its noisy when lightly loaded, but very quiet with a 215 pound load ;-). The photo was taken after the load test!
Sorry about the faceting on the race; Sketchup's follow me function is not all that impressive.

First, verify that a roller will roll around the race freely; a slight tilt should send it running smoothly around.  You can either run it full complement (by filling the groove completely with tapered rollers), or use the cage.  The cage pins fit into the holes through the rollers.

comments.text: Yeah, I'll probably re-draw it using circles rather than follow-me.  The polygons do add noise.
comments.author: Weldingrod1

comments.text: When using the follow me increase the sides of the object you are following. When yo click on a circle the first number you can enter are the sides, default of 24, to a larger number.
comments.author: Weldingrod1

comments.text: My later tries incorporated more polygons.  I built one with MUCH larger rollers and a larger taper angle also, but the dratted rollers don't actually roll!
comments.author: smartroad

comments.text: Can you turn up your polygons on the circles?  I bet it would run smoother if the "tracks" in the race didn't have those corners?
comments.author: Mjolnir

comments.text: Polar-polar?  Sounds interesting.... any more details or are you going to leave us hanging?

title: MX5 NA Miata Seat Belt Extension

description.text:
These are seat belt extensions which are used so that you don't have to make the big reach every time to put your seatbelt on. They attach to the chassis stiffener bar. In order to clear the plastic, a 6mm washer is required, but also included. I have included a 10mm washer too if the 6mm doesn't give you the clearance you want. The washer is installed between the stiffener bar and the chassis.

Although the belt extension adds a little friction to the retract function on the seatbelt, the seat belt still performs all of its functions without a problem so you get added convenience with no risk to your safety. That being said... use it at you own risk...

90%

Notes:

This is the right hand side extension. For the left simply mirror in repetier or similar
You will note there are two 1mm bridge supports for each side of the belt retainer overhangs. These need to be remove and the edges filed to match the rounded edges.

author: emosolo

description.text: Madagascar 3d Silhouettes

A small robotic hand driven by a cheep 9g servo, printed fully assembled in one piece.

This is designed for a 0.4mm nozzle and 0.2mm layer height, the tolerances are very tight so if you have any over-extrusion this will not printed correctly.

This model needs support so the gears aren't fused to the surfaces below and above them - but the supports have to be small and breakable, Cura's support everywhere settings works fine, Slic3r default supports are massive and will probably not work.

When you take the hand off the buildplate the "finger" edges should look like they are touching but shouldn't be fused at all.

You need to remove the supports holding the motor coupling before anything else, otherwise the shaft connecting it to the gears might break.

After removing the support just pull the "fingers" apart, you need to apply some force to break the supports but it shouldn't be too difficult.

Open and close the hand a few times to wear out the supports and make it easier to the servo, if the servo can't push the hand its not exactly centered.

This model was designed with SketchUp the STL files were fixed with Microsoft 3D Builder, it was then sliced with Cura and printed on my Robo3D R1+

Video of it working at https://youtu.be/LVSO88PG15k

comments.text: Oh wow! You and I must have had the same idea because I just made something like this a month ago, I've just forgotten to upload it! One suggestion I might make is to make the servo horn connector thicker, those little SG92Rs have quite a bit of torque, in my design the gear fits directly on the servo horn.

As part of my artist residency at the Innovation Lab i am delivering a series of workshops over a one month period to introduce people to 3d scanning with 123D Catch. Last weekend i led a group of participants in my 3D scanning workshop on a short "architectural tour" of the Loop in Chicago. First we checked out the Fisher Building, The Old Colony Building and then  moved onto the park. We scanned a number of the public art pieces and local scenery.  
This Crest is part of a larger item - i'm not even sure what it is called - but it's kinda cool and the scan came out really well.
i have included all the source files for reference. i did not scan the whole object. i used Blender to extrude the wireframe to create a manifold mesh and then cut it down to size in Netfabb.

This is a paddle shifter system for 280 mm and larger diameter steering wheels with 70 mm bolt mounting pattern. This design can be built with only shifters or shifters + buttons, wired or wireless via BT.

The complete shifter consists of two shifter assemblies and a base plate. The shifter unit and paddle hinge should be 3D printed. Paddle and steering wheel mount plate can be printed, but I recommend laser cutting or CNC milling for maximum rigidity.

The shifter has a nice and well defined click. It is magnetically returned, and it uses a micro switch. It mounts to the back side of any steering wheel with standard 70 mm bolt pattern.

YouTube video showing paddle shifter operation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pz5LogKsN7o

BOM:

  • Printed / laser / cnc-cut parts
  • 4x 8mm dia, 5mm tall neodymium magnet
  • 2x KW10 long r shaped lever micro switches (from ebay, 13 x 6 mm footprint)
  • 10 mm M3 mounting hardware for paddle, shifter base mount and end-of-travel stop
  • 28 mm M3 mounting hardware for shifter units
  • 3 mm rod for paddle hinge
  • Some hot glue, epoxy or CA-glue

Notes: The parts are not in optimal print orientation. Rotate them before printing. Some nut holes are closed with 0,2 mm thick extrude to improve print quality, use a small drill or a file to open them after printing. The shifter paddle in real world pictures is different from the one that is available for download.

Update 1: Added a shifter mount plate with buttons. It accepts buttons with 12 mm mounting hole diameter. I used buttons with 16 mm housing outer diameter.

Update 2: Added shifter mount plate /w buttons version 2. The buttons are arranged further away from wheel center. This version also comes as a variant, that has mounting holes for wireless hardware & two status indicator leds

Update 3: Added wireless instructions, wireless base station enclosure and F1 style paddles

Update 4: Added a stronger paddle hinge to fix the small flex in the paddle. Print hinge with high infill. PLA, PETT or PETG recommended.

Overview

This button & shifter combo can be made wireless via Bluetooth. The system has about 15ms of measured lag, which is about 1 frame in a game. The base station appears as a game controller for a PC. Building the wireless system requires some electrical skills. The wireless side was developed by me and my friend Mika, code is available in GitHub, compile with Arduino + Teensyduino IDE.

https://github.com/mtakala/simracing_wireless_buttons

Wheel setup

Refer to software project git for exact wiring. Each button should be wired to one I/O pin in Teensy and ground of Teensy. Wheel software can read battery voltage, but the max voltage for Teensy ADC is 3.3V, thus voltage division is necessary. 10k + 3.3k divider works ok with max 4.2v (3.7v nominal) LiPo. The GND, VCC, TX, RX and status pins of HC-05 should be connected to Teensy. The battery and status indicator LEDs should have current limiting resistors of about 80 ohms if using regular LEDs.

It is recommended to compile the wheel side with 24 MHz Teensy CPU speed to reduce current consumption and improve battery life. I am using 16 MHz no USB mode and it seems to work fine. With lower than stock Teensy clock speed, this setup works easily 12 hours, maybe up to 24 hours with 500 mAh battery.

BOM:

  • Teensy 3.2
  • HC-05 BT module
  • 3.7V LiPo, my lipo is 500mAh and ~ 48 x 20 x 8 mm
  • Two LEDs for battery and link status indication
  • Resistors for LEDs and battery voltage division
Base station setup

The base station is easy to wire up, the pre-configured HC-05 BT unit just has to be connected to Teensy, requiring power, TX, RX and status pin wires. The code in GitHub lists specific pins. USB HID is done via same USB port as programming.

Compile with Teensy configured as USB FlightSimControls + Joystick. 72 MHz core clock recommended, although it should not matter much as the software is lightweight.

BOM:

  • Teensy 3.2
  • HC-05 BT module
  • 28 mm M3 bolts and nuts for enclosure
  • Some hot glue to mount electronics
  • LEDs and current limit resistors for power and connection indication (optional)

comments.author: jkoljo

comments.text: This Looks good, But any way you can show a image of it all connected close up? i am very lost on the power connections. and is it the same for base and wheel?
comments.author: jkoljo

comments.text: Yes, the BT module connections are the same, but on the wheel side you have to deal with a battery. Usually you can just connect 1 cell battery directly to Teensy, but if your battery has a higher voltage, you need to regulate it first. The base side gets power from PC USB. I found this picture of connections, I hope it helps (check that the pins match your BT module! And remember TX goes to RX and RX to TX): https://sourpuss.net/projects/trains/computer/hc06_schem.png
comments.author: Wilts3DesignEng

comments.text:
so with that picture the BT is getting power form the Teensy. and this is ok on both the Base and Wheel?
Base uses USB connection and Wheel is Battery. What Resistors are needed?
comments.author: jkoljo

comments.text: Yes it is. Resistors are necessary to limit the LED current, so when you connect a LED to teensy, you need to have a resistor in series with it. 100 ohm resistors would be ok for both LEDs. You also need voltage division resistors for battery voltage sensing. This is a bit more tricky. You can only feed Teensy a maximum of 1.2 volts, so full battery voltage may not exceed that after a voltage reduction circuit. For example R1 10kOhm and R2 3.3kOhm would work: http://www.ohmslawcalculator.com/voltage-divider-calculator -> the output + goes to teensy pin 23.

description.text: The scroll case may find use whenever one needs to transport a short missive in a dignified, weather-resistant container. Read about how I used one of these to 3d print a time capsule during the repainting of Casa de Zheng. Use a medium length of sturdy ribbon to fasten the scroll case snugly between a raven's wings, with an X-harness across the bird's keel. Can also hold a small quantity of iocaine powder.

The cap and tube should fit together snugly, but if you would like the cap to be  silently removable I suggest wiping the interior plug with a little acetone. This will smooth out the ridges left by the printing process and reduce friction when inserting into the tube.  
A 55mmx140mm sheet of paper will roll nicely and fit into the tube. A template .svg is included for your convenience. Ciphering and encryption of messages is left as an exercise for the reader.

comments.text: You could always run a ribbon through the rolled message around the rolled length to get something to pull the roll out of the tube.
comments.author: cckens

comments.text: It printed just fine but beware connecting strands inside the case. I rammed it clean with a knitting needle. Even then, the 55x140mm size listed for a message seems over generous. I couldn't get the message to go inside until I trimmed it down to 55x70mm -- then after getting it inserted I realized I had no way of getting it out. I used a bent paper clip, but I'd recommend much smaller message sizes, perhaps 55x40mm would be enough to avoid ripping the message on removal.

title: Ultraportable Yagi-Uda antenna for VHF/UHF
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The idea behind this project is to provide a basket of parts out of which anyone can assemble his or her customized Yagi-Uda antenna for VHF/UHF. For my initial 2m - antenna an additional goal was to come up with an ultraportable design. Both was achieved and if you want to create your own one, this is what you will need in addition to the 3D-printed parts:

Bill of materials:
Aluminum square tube, outer dimension 20 mm of appropriate length
Aluminum tube, outer diam. 6 mm, wall thickness 1mm of the appropriate length for radiator, reflector(s) and director(s)
(Min.) 100 mm threaded rod, M5
(Min.) 8 nuts, M5
2 nuts: 1/4'' USC
1 BNC-connector
2 solder lugs for 5 mm
2 plastic caps for the aluminum square tube

As you will have to cut M5 inner threads into the aluminum tubes you will also need the respective tools for that.

The design for my 3-element 2m band antenna is described in detail in the magazine "Funkamateur 09/2015". These are the dimensions (tip to tip): reflector 1034 mm, radiator 988 mm, director 884 mm. The distance between the radiator rods at the feedpoint is 10 mm, distance between reflector and radiator 350 mm and between reflector and director 600 mm. Most convenient - and the reason for "cuttting in halve" of director and reflector - is the fact that all the element parts fit inside the squared aluminum tube which acts at the same time as the mounting bracket for the antenna. Thus the antenna is just 62 cm long and a few centimeters wide for transport and well protected.

The attachment part for a tripod is designed in such a way, that the antenna can be mounted horizontally as well as vertically. The USC-nuts have to be glued in their places, preferrably using a 2 component epoxy resin. As the antenna should stay clear of conducting parts (e.g. tripod) it is advisable to increase the distance to the tripod by means of an extension (like:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1641926). It is also a good idea to reduce common mode, for example by attaching a foldable ferrite or some turns of the antenna cable.

Printer:

BQ Hephestos

author: werobotsnoia

print_settings.Notes:: 100% infill seems to work best

description.text:
Flexible watch band with mesh pattern - great for exercise/sports, breathes well and won't get damaged by water.

It is designed with an integrated buckle that prints as part of the strap.

Designed for a Pebble Time Round, but will fit other watches with 20mm band.

Needs to be printed with ninjaflex or other flexible filament. You'll also need two 20mm spring-loaded watch band pins from another strap or purchased from a jeweller.

Print 2 copies of the strap loop.

If you want a plain band without the mesh holes, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1678188

This is the first version of this design, so if you have any suggestions / requests, please post a comment and I'll do my best to incorporate them in the next iteration!

Infill:

100%

Notes:

A few tips for printing:

  • 100% infill seems to work best
  • Shell 1mm or above will result in better quality and faster printing for this part (since it reduces infill in the mesh part of the strap)
  • If your slicer allows it, turning "combing" on can help reduce stringing across the holes in the mesh
  • Setting minimum time per layer to a reasonable value (5-10s) can help avoid the peg part of the band fastener coming out melted-looking

1. Clean up any rough spots

Using a craft knife, cut off any left-over blobs of plastic etc., especially from the inside of the band (the side that will be against your wrist) as these can be uncomfortable if not cleaned up.

2. Attach band loops

Put both of the rectangular band loops onto the buckle side of the band. There are a couple of small tabs on the side of the strap which are meant to hold one of the loops in front of the peg.

3. Attach bands to watch case

Take a spring-loaded watch band pin and put it into the hole at the end of the strap.
If there is any excess plastic left inside the pin hole, you may need to clean it out first. I used a 2mm drill bit for this.
Put one end of the pin into the hole on the watch case lug, and use a pocket knife or other implement to compress the spring-loaded pin enough that it can fit inside the other lug. Make sure it lines up with the hole - it should click into place.

Repeat for the other strap.

4. Fasten watch band

With the watch on your wrist, pass the end of the long strap through the hole in the end of the other strap, then through the first band loop and over the top of the peg. (This can be a bit fiddly, I'm trying to think of improvements to the design in this area)

Tighten the strap, and push the peg through one of the hexagonal holes running down the centre of the strap. Then push the end of the long strap through the second band loop.

Have a look at the photos attached to this thing to get a better idea of how this works.

comments.text: ninjatek Seems to advice against long term exposure to water as it will reduce ninjaflex's elasticity.

I'm working my way toward a color mixing extruder for my Emaker Huxley.  These two extruder bodies incorporate filament guides (oriented for the Huxley) and are arranged to be stackable.  The one that takes markers would, of course, use white filament...

The extruder body without the markers will stack as high as you want.  You will need to trim one of the feet where it touches the marker style extruder because it doesn't have the mating bump that the stackable one has; sorry!  You should use my filament hold down clamp 14317 with this.

remixed_from.author: eiPionezero
remixed_from.title: 2-in-1 fan duct: extruder and filament cooler for E3D V6 and others

title: 2in1 cooler for wanhao i3 v2 and cacoon create (abandoned)

description.text:
Edit: 11/6/16 Some video footage on testing the cooler https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5kIOr68WA9Y&t=0s . https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eYOEj2fIPa4
Edit: 11/6/16 I found out from another user that did some in-depth testing that this design does steal quite a bit of air from the rest of the assembly. That said I can't really recommend using it. I am also considering deleting it from the site as well.

Edit: 11/1/16 I have finally decided to "finish" this cooling idea. It feels more like abandoning then finishing. I do feel that I have reached the end of what this small mod can do. I am also working towards ways to "upgrade" this concept. This cooler may be finished, but the idea is still with me.

I designed this to help cooling with the stock fan. It works on my wanhao i3 and could work with a wanhao V 2.1, Wanhao i3 plus, cocoon create, Maker select, and malyan m150. Without access to these printers I cannot say for sure.

Edit: 8/18/16 After seeing the issues I went to work on trying to fix them. Now I have updated the stl file and put an F on the model to identify it as updated. This new version has a slimmer end so its not as close to the hot end. I have also reduced the end outlet as a result of slimming it. This however seems to have also fixed the hot end heat rob I saw on the original. I posted 2 screenshots showing how far it was changing on my machine. I put the fan duct on my printer and heated the hot end to normal printing temps I use. Extruded some filament, then left it for a few minuets before removing. The part was not melted or deformed when I removed it from my printer. The file Fanduct2mm simply has 2mm added to the end. It slightly shits the air curve coming from the duct. I suggest trying it if you are having any heat rob problems.

Edit: 8/14/16 After using it for about two weeks I can say it somehow manages to give a similar hot end heat rob as the Dii cooler had. Which I did not expect in all honestly. It also had enough power to disturb filament strands hanging from the hot end. Stopped using it because I have been using PETG filament. Which needs more fan control than PLA. Only had one problem of the part being deformed slightly at the end from heat.

Edit: 7/20/2016 Decided to use it myself and see the ups and downs to it, all ready competed several PETG prints using it.

This is my attempt to make a fan shroud that pulls from the main cooling block fan. More of a concept for someone more skilled to refine. I got my inspiration after seeing eiPionezero 2 in 1 fan duct. This splitter can work with the stock 30 mm fan on the v2. It needs extended screws to be applied to the stock printer. I used m3 X 50 in the pictures. IMPORTANT PLEASE READ- The space between the X limit switch and the fan is very small, so it may just be too big for your printer. You can see that in my pictures.
It should be 10mm wide, I might can reduce that some if people need it. Personally I use a blower fan on my printer, so I do not know how well this helps the stock fan cool. I just wanted to create something for the wanhao community after all the help they gave me . Test it out and let me know if its any good.

Printer:

Wanhao duplicator i3 v2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1 for myself

Infill:

50% for the one in the pictures

Notes:

I used build plate supports to make the entry way more clean. But that was more of a personal choice.

comments.text: I don't know if it's a great idea to divert any anything away from the extruder fan. It doesn't take much to heat up the stepper motor and soften filament before it enters the heat brake. Something as minor as putting the heat sync backwards will adversely effect your printer.
comments.author: ansonjames

comments.text: I did complete a few test prints with some makergeeks pla and petg in the past. The prints looked okay, however I expect pulling from the fan would have effects. Thinking about slapping it back on and doing some long prints. Sadly I don't have anything like a FLIR to see the exact temp changes.
comments.author: ansonjames

comments.text: I did a 14 hour print yesterday with the cooler. Everything seemed cool enough, at-least to the touch. I have some ideas on how to try to "upgrade" this concept. So I am calling this one "finished" and moving on.
comments.author: FilamentCorner

comments.text: totally agreed.

description.text:
This is the first thing I have designed for 3D printing, an Ikea wall spacer that is extra long for when you have to place furniture in front of power outlets but want to secure it properly. It replaces Ikea part numbers 141413 and 141414. It fits Bestå cupboards and various other Ikea lines.

This object gives you 120mm of clearance behind your piece of furniture to the wall.

The minimum screw size you can get away to secure your furniture to the wall using this object is 150mm long 5mm or 6mm wide - the hole in the middle accommodates 6mm wide screws maximum.

New version (v4) changes:

  • Accommodates 6mm screws which are more easily obtainable 150mm in length

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro 2016

Yes

Yes

25%

Ensure enough infill - at least 25% - due to pressure on the object from the screw. 25% will probably do as the large metal Ikea washer spreads this out a bit.

title: Smartphone Car Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
KFZ Smartphone-Halter im „Bass-Look“ für Sony Xperia Z5
Grundüberlegung war es, für mein Auto (Golf IV) einen Handyhalter zu konstruieren, welcher in der Lüftung befestigt wird.
Da kam mein Hobby, Bass spielen, ganz gelegen.
Die Halter für den Lüfter sind abschraubbar und können somit individuell angepasst werden bzw. andere Formen für andere Lüfter einfach ausgedruckt werden.
Gleichzeitig dient der Halter als Dockingstation des Gerätes.
Optisch für Freunde der Musik natürlich sehr Ansprechend.

Car smartphone holder in “bass optic” for Sony Xperia Z5
Basic consideration was to create a smartphone holder for my car which one can secured in the ventilation.
I thought that I need something with personality so I choose my hobby, playing electric bass.
The holders for the ventilation are unscrewed so they could be adjusted or you can print some new holder for your ventilation.
The holder can use at once as a docking station.
When you are a friend of music then you will love this.

Printer:

description.text:
250 quadcopter frame

There are two types of frames the V and X type, in the X type the front and the back arms are 1 piece, while on the V type there are 4 different arms, I still haven't printed it so i don't know which one is better, as soon as i'll print it i'll let you know.

-V type, you need:
x4 v-arms
x2 v-arm lock
x1 top
x1 v-bottom
x8 spacer
x1 fpv camera(if you have one)(10 degrees inclination)
x1 hd camera(if you have one)

X type, you need:

x4 x-arms
x2 x-arm lock
x1 top
x1 x-bottom
x8 spacer
x1 fpv camera(if you have one)(10 degrees inclination)
x1 hd camera(if you have one)

MY SETUP:

-Motors: BG2204 2300KV Brushless Motor x2 CW and X2 CCW
( http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-Racer-250-Drone-Spare-Part-BG2204-2300KV-Brushless-Motor-CWCCW-p-1007680.html)

-ESCs: BL20A x4
(http://www.banggood.com/BL20A-OneShot-125-OPTO-2-4s-Mini-Brushless-20A-BLHeli-ESC-For-FPV-QAV180-250-p-1023318.html)

-Flight controller: CC3D
(http://www.banggood.com/it/Spedix-CC3D-Flight-Controller-Connected-Directly-To-DSM2-DSMX-Satellite-S_Bus-p-977491.html)

-Propellers: Kingkong 5040
(http://www.banggood.com/it/10-Pairs-KINGKONG-5040-Propellers-For-QAV250-p-1000415.html)

-Fpv setup: Eachine 700TVL
(http://eu.banggood.com/it/Wholesale-Warehouse-Eachine-700TVL-13-Cmos-FPV-110-Degree-Camera-w32CH-Transmission-wp-Eu-965760.html)

For the look i took inspiration from the Peon230 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:629338)

Qlive 3d printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 layer height

Arm and arm lock's infill = 100%, other parts = 50%

Notes:

I'll print it in ABS, but the spacers, the fpv camera piece can be printed in PLA

For the arm and arm lock i suggest a 100% infill, while for the other parts is up to you, 30% infill if you want it lighter, 50% or 60% if you want it stronger.

You also need some M3 screws and nuts.

print_settings.Notes:: Bearing supports are stronger when printed in ABS or PETG.

title: XY Bearings Offset remix for longer travel

description.text:
I noticed on the original Smartrapcore ALU / XL300, as the Y carriage moved towards the back of the machine the belt teeth began to interlock and started to affect movement in that area. I've redesigned the two rear bearing holders to support the bearing offset and supported from the top and bottom side to reduce the cantilever effect due to belt tensions.

You should need to print 1 of each bearing support, and 4 spacers using the existing parts from the Smartrapcore ALU/XL300 build along with a shorter M8 bolt to act as an axis.

Designed on Onshape at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/bf73580fded0a3ddee7e63c7/w/a4ebe5fdf466658b538d5071/e/d0562b45f4cb7f900afaf7ba

description.text:
I tend to listen to music/podcasts on my phone whilst mowing my lawn, the earphone cord is too long though and liable to getting caught on things!

I liked the design of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:268764 but wanted something that was easier to print without supports (note that Raplicator appears to now have a version that is better for printing flat). Plus I wanted an exercise to practice using 123D Design on as at the time I was new to the program, this seemed the perfect solution and a nice quick model to test the print on.

I decided to keep a as close to the overall shape as possible and to also keep the idea of the contour channel for the cord to sit in, but flatten the overall design. I created the model from scratch so the profile does differ slightly from the shape of Raplicator's original.

description.text: My kids and people I work with are all playing Pokemon Go :-) and I still know that game from the time my kids were young. I sat down and decided to create a pokeball keychain. Its aboud 40 mm diameter and 3 mm thick. I created three different parts, one for the red parts, one for the white parts and one for the black parts. If you print them all they will click together to create a nice keychain. I used some glue in the back of the black container to make the keychain stronger. The files all contain two parts, so you can make two keychains in one print. This part was (of course) created with FreeCad and sliced using Cura.

description.text:
This is a battery case for the standard size battery on a 1981 GL500. It may or may not work for a CX500. The case is in place of the H-box below the engine.

Two prints interlock and all you require to complete this box is three bolts and nuts to secure it.

Battery is held in my rope/string through the front holes.
Modified version has slot for a 1 inch strap

Front cover in progress : )
An early design for a parametrizable permanent magnet alternator. Or structure for a one.

6.2. 2012, update to rotor: Attempt to add placeholders for washers and extend magnet through the rotor. Also updated assembly-routine with MK6-turbine (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16504). Check the scad for rotor and stator routines.
Rotor.stl is just an example generated. I imagine the magnets would need to be epoxied in place. Although I made the script more or less from scratch, design is inspired by:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1589
(coil shape and winder are something that could be used/shared in future from Gene_Hackers design) Electronics/coil design has not been really started for this, but what I initially checked there was no shortage of research and experiments there.
  • Design magnets and coils setup
  • Edit corresponding parameters in scad
  • render with rotor() and stator()
    • NOTE: although rotor might be getting somewhere, don't print the STL (it's too large for most printers anyways).

comments.text: With the right strength of the magnets, with the right wire diameter, with the right distance from the magnet with the right coil core at the right speed this design can go over-unity. I made a full size muller generator 13 years ago and with 30 coils, after more than 6 years with R&D I got Over Unity and fully looped and charging a battery bank for save energy that is not used in the peaks of the consumer day. The input to the engine who runs the generator is 8.82 Watt. The output from every coil was at its highest 7.01 Watt and at the lowest 3.12 Watt, with means that with all 30 coils it produced more out than put in.
comments.author: rdavm

comments.text: Air coil design.  We have to find a way to make it more efficient because of the relatively low speeds the turbine turns at (Typically the blades move at twice the wind speed - you can work out RPM for your support radius at the average wind speed for your area)

title: Laser Spirograph
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Laser Spirograph (meant as a tree topper)

DO NOT USE A LASER STRONGER THAN 5mW (Class IIIa) FOR THIS DEVICE! This has not been tested by anyone to be safe for lasers stronger than 5mW. If the motor drivers stall and the laser happens to be pointing at your eye, you will not see out of that eye any more. This is serious, folks!!!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p59LU9QrhCM

BOM:
Two vibration motors - you can pick up at Radio Shack. https://www.radioshack.com/products/radioshack-3vdc-micro-vibration-motor?variant=5717362821
Laser Module - I got mine off ebay (100 mW with TTL control) but it looks exactly like this one: http://odicforce.com/epages/05c54fb6-7778-4d36-adc0-0098b2af7c4e.sf/en_GB/?ObjectPath=/Shops/05c54fb6-7778-4d36-adc0-0098b2af7c4e/Products/OFL194
1" square mirror tiles - like you would find at a craft store
Arduino - I use Arduino Pro Minis for practically everything.

Use SpiroMount5 or SpiroMount10 depending on the throw you want. The SpiroMount10 will result in a much wider angle (10 degrees vs. 5 degrees) for a larger projection.

How it works:

Each motor's power is treated as a coordinate in a vector that describes how fast each motor is spinning. Each motor's power is continually modified by an "inertia" that changes signs and is randomized in magnitude when the power reaches the maximum or minimum allowed power.

The motors, like most motors, need a higher starting power than needed to maintain rotation. Thus at startup, before the laser is turned on, both motors are turned to max for half a second.

At very low powers, the motors can stall and idle to a stop, thus the motors are assigned a stall speed. If both motor's power is below that stall speed for two cycles of execution (3s), one motor at random will be kicked up to max speed for 1.5 seconds (the update time of the loop)

Please note, to use this in a public place with a >5mW laser, you'll need a CDRH permit or variance. To obtain the permit you'll need to implement independent stall detection. If either motor is stalled, you should cut the laser beam with TTL or a mechanical shutter. This should kick in FASTER than the above described code for a CDRH approval. I believe the guidelines is <= 25ms, but you should certainly investigate yourself as I am not a mechanical engineer, laser safety professional, lawyer, or employee of the FDA (who administer the CDRH guidelines) If you're interested in using this device in public, this page seems like a good place to start: http://www.fda.gov/Radiation-EmittingProducts/RadiationEmittingProductsandProcedures/HomeBusinessandEntertainment/ucm118907.htm

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

Cupcake CNC

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm layer

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Minor warping on base - does not affect final product alignment

Assembly

For each mount, snap in a mirror, then push the mount onto the motor. You may use a drop of superglue inside the hole to help secure it, but I found friction fit was plenty strong. Then use the included clamps to clamp each motor in place. Finally place the laser in its place and use the included clamps to attach it.

When I was done I cut a sqaure in a Radio Shack project box, glued in a piece of PC / Lexan to protect the mirrors and laser from dust, and shoved everything in side. The box gets zip-tied to the top of my christmas tree every year!

To control it, wire up an Arduino as follows:

Laser TTL control - pin 9
Motor power - pins 10 and 11

And install the laserspiro.ino sketch

Design

This was mocked up in OpenSCAD. Unfortunately I've lost my .scad file in the meantime since creating it!

title: E3D V6 Adapter and DC42 Differential IR sensor mount

description.text:
Using the Official E3D V6 hotend required a different mount to lower the hotend below the level of the x-axis min endstop switch. This is my remix of the original jhead mount.

I've also switched to using the DC42 Differential IR sensor which required a different bracket that still uses the same mounting holes from the inductive sensor. (This part may need modification if your using a different hotend but it works for the E3D V6 and E3D Lite6 hotends.)

Designed in Onshape:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/df1930401d5350ef2521663b/w/2a8fb45251b1811ec75f5d03/e/bddac8db7c320469b9c43db7

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Smartrapcore Alu

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.254 layer height

Infill:

30%

comments.text: Thanks for all the ALU customizations!  What 40mm fan mount are you using with your E3D?  I've tried a couple and haven't found one I'm happy with.
comments.author: atheimer

comments.text: I'm not using a 40mm fan.  I use the standard E3D 30mm fans that come with the hotends.
comments.author: atheimer
